entry.title: How to improve the performance of prepared statements over stored procedures on SAP ASE 16?
entry.content:
I am using SAP (Sybase) Adaptive Server Enterprise (ASE) 16. I am using jConnect 4 in version 7.07. The application I'm working on serves thousands of users concurrently. It is a Java monolith hosted on ~ 5 different VMs. So multiple Java process on multiple VMs with different connections are executing mainly procedures and some statements.

I have a stored procedure that contains a rather simple query, equivalent to this one (I have changed the column names for this example):

select o.item_id, o.option_uuid, c.product_description, o.option_size
from options_rm o
left join options_products_rm c on c.id = o.product_id
where o.item_id = @item_id

At peak load, there are about 1200 executions in a given 30 seconds window of this procedure. On average, the procedure takes about 1.31 ms to complete.

I have now replaced the stored procedure with a prepared statement using the exact same SQL query. There are no comments inside the SQL query.

The prepared statement takes about 1.8 ms to complete. This is about 37 % longer than the stored procedure. The same phenomenon happens when applied to other prepared statements compared to stored procedures.

Here is a quick rundown of the Sybase ASE database setup:

  • Since I am using jConnect 4, DYNAMIC_PREPARE should be true by default.
  • The statement cache size is set to 2048 memory pages (2K).
  • The memory used of statement cache size is 4784 kilobytes.
  • streamlined dynamic SQL is enabled.
  • enable literal autoparam is enabled.
  • dynamic sql plan pinning is enabled.
  • enable plan sharing is enabled.
  • optimizer level is set to ase_current.

Why does the prepared statement take so much longer than the procedure, even though its execution plan etc. should already be cached? How can I improve the performance of prepared statements on SAP ASE 16?

entry.title: Product Compliance in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP's ready-to-run public cloud ERP software solution.  

 SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data, and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the cloud ERP ecosystem‚Äìcustomers, partners, and SAP experts.  

 

In this blog post I‚Äôd like to outline the innovations for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 in the area of Product Compliance. These are the topics that are covered:

  • Classifying dangerous goods packaged in logistics packing instructions (3FC)
  • EU safety data sheet generation for first scenarios and product groups (7DO)
  • Support of branded products in the safety data sheet process (3VR)

In case you do not need all the information below and briefly want to get an overview of the release highlights, please watch this video with the top three key innovations:

 

 

Video#1: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 for Product Compliance

 

Classifying dangerous goods packaged in logistics packing instructions

 

Business Background

This feature revolutionizes compliance management by enabling users to manage and maintain compliance for products packaged through logistics instructions from handling unit management. By seamlessly integrating with our existing classification app for packaged products, this innovation allows businesses to comply with various dangerous goods regulations more efficiently. The integration not only enhances accuracy in classification but also simplifies the overarching regulatory processes, reducing the complexity traditionally associated with managing dangerous goods.

 

Key Feature

This enhancement facilitates a systematic approach to compliance, leveraging the strengths of both classification apps to forge a cohesive, streamlined process. Companies can now ensure that compliance standards are met across the board by aligning logistic packing instructions with the regulatory demands of dangerous goods. This capability ultimately results in a more coherent compliance strategy that mitigates potential risks and fosters a safer operational environment.

 

Video#2: Classifying dangerous goods packaged in logistics packing instructions

 

EU safety data sheet generation for first scenarios and product groups

 

Business Background

Our safety data sheet (SDS) generation feature has received significant enhancement to support first scenarios and product groups, particularly tailored for European Union compliance requirements. Leveraging integrated regulatory content for GHS specification, this feature ensures that your safety data sheets are comprehensive and meet the highest standards. One of the standout aspects is its incorporation of a starter template, allowing for customization to fit the unique needs of your business while maintaining compliance integrity.

 

Key Feature

A key complement to this is the new preview functionality, which offers the ability to verify end products before distribution, adding an essential layer of quality assurance in documentation. By ensuring the accuracy and compliance of each document before it reaches stakeholders, the enhancement minimizes the risk of non-compliance and potential disruptions. This innovative solution not only supports compliance practices but enhances them, offering a smooth path to achieving regulatory standards.

 

 

Video#3: EU safety data sheet generation for first scenarios and product groups

 

Support of branded products in the safety data sheet process

 

Business Background

Our third key innovation is the support for branded products within the SDS process, which provides an entirely new dimension to product compliance management. This feature allows businesses to create and manage branded products distinctly from unpackaged or packaged ones, ensuring that they are accurately reflected in safety data sheets and other critical compliance documents. This added layer of flexibility allows organizations to represent their product portfolio authentically, while still adhering to rigorous compliance requirements.

 

Key Feature

In addition, the branded products support means that businesses can optimize their regulatory processes for product differentiation, enabling them to stand out in the market while maintaining stringent compliance. By integrating branded names and specific product branding details into compliance documentation, companies are provided with the tools to navigate complex brand management issues with ease. This feature is especially useful for businesses with extensive product lines, permitting them to handle compliance needs across diverse product offerings seamlessly.

 

Video#4: Support of branded products in the safety data sheet process



The value proposition we offer with Release 2508 is substantial. By integrating these innovations, we empower organizations to manage their product compliance with unprecedented ease and efficiency. You gain reliable compliance mechanisms that support global trade, mitigate risks, and protect your reputation. Our tools also help reduce administrative overhead and expedite the time-to-market by automating complex tasks and diminishing potential errors in compliance processes.

Thanks for taking the time to read this blog.

Don‚Äôt hesitate to leave a comment and check out our community page to ask your questions and engage with the experts. Follow the PSCC_Enablement tag to stay up to date with our latest blog posts. 

 

More Information

 

If you want to learn more in-depth, just a heads-up that from September 30th to October 2nd, the virtual EHS & Product Compliance Infodays are taking place. You can register here to see the agenda and join the event.



üìΩÔ∏è Watch the replays of our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Early Release Series! 

From July 21-25, we hosted a series of 21 compelling live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release. Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you. You will find the recording and presentation for LoB/Industry/Topic as well as 20 other topics of interest. Don't miss this chance and watch them on demand‚Äìanywhere, anytime.

entry.title: Re: BEHAVIOR_STATEMENT_ILLEGAL error using EML for entity...
entry.content:
Hello @TajShaik 

You‚Äôre encountering BEHAVIOR_STATEMENT_ILLEGAL because MODIFY ENTITIES (EML) is only allowed during the interaction phase and within the finalise method of a saver, not during save/commit processing or in UPDATE TASK contexts. In your flow, after posting the material document via the public API‚Äîwhich triggers its own save/commit‚Äîyour action continues in a state where EML is not permitted, hence the dump. SAP Help Portal/ABAP Keyword Documentation

What needs to be changed
Choose one of these supported patterns

  1. Do the EML update earlier (interaction phase).
    Update I_ServiceOrderTP.requestedServiceStartDateTime before calling the material document API, such as during the interaction phase. SAP Help Portal
  2. Split the steps into two LUWs.
    After the API finishes, trigger the service-order update in a separate behaviour session (e.g., an asynchronous follow-up or a small wrapper that runs after commit), or call the released OData API for Service Order in a new HTTP call‚Äîoutside the current save. (EML across a foreign BO is not allowed during save.) SAP Help Portal
  3. Only for the same BO changes in save:
    If you must adjust your own BO during save, use MODIFY ENTITIES **IN LOCAL MODE** inside finalise but this works only for the same BO, not for I_ServiceOrderTP (a foreign/reuse BO). SAP Help Portal

Why the dump points to CL_IRES_RESERVATION...
That class shows you where you are in the runtime that processes the save/commit logic. In that status, EML modify is disallowed by design. SAP Help Portal/Save Sequence Runtime

References

  • ABAP Keyword Doc ‚Äì MODIFY ENTITY/ENTITIES usage restrictions (allowed phases). SAP Help Portal ABAP Keyword Documentation
  • SAP Help ‚Äì Interaction phase & save sequence (where EML is legal). SAP Help Portal/Implementing the Interaction Phase and the Save Sequence

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Custom CDS view Partner OrganizationName1 display
entry.content:
Hello @ISoma 

Following up on your question regarding the inclusion of Ship-To partner address details for example Name1, street and city into your Custom CDS View for Service Contracts, here is the recommended approach for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

  1. First is the Base Data Source. Continue using your service contract interface view as the primary source.
  2. The next thing is to join to Service Contract Partners
  • Add an association to I_ServiceContractPartner.
  • Join on ServiceContract = ServiceContract.
  • You need to expose BusinessPartner (Ship-To BP), AddressID (if maintained) and PartnerFunction (to filter Ship-To, typically function code = WE).
  1. Therafter you should join to Business Partner, add an association to I_BusinessPartner, Join on BusinessPartner = ShipToBP. Then expose, organizationBPName1 (maps to the classic Name1 field). Optionally you can also expose, OrganizationBPName2 and BusinessPartnerFullName.
  2. Then join to Business Partner Address
  • Add an association to I_BusinessPartnerAddress.
  • Join on BusinessPartner = ShipToBP and AddressID = ShipToAddressID.
  • Expose:
    • StreetName, CityName, PostalCode, Country, and any other needed address attributes.
  • If no AddressID is stored, you can fall back to the standard address by joining only on BusinessPartner and filtering IsStandardAddress = 'X'.
  1. Here are some analytical considerations to make
  • Mark address and name fields as attributes rather than measures.
  • Keep associations as LEFT OUTER joins so that contracts without a Ship-To partner still appear in analytics.
  • If you need a reporting layer, create a consumption CDS view on top and expose the same attributes.

To summarise, by combining the three released interface views (I_ServiceContractPartner, I_BusinessPartner, and I_BusinessPartnerAddress), you can safely expose Ship-To partner name and address information in your Service Contract analytical cube. This method is fully compatible with Public Cloud extensibility and upgrade safe.

I hope this provides the desired result. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Monitor/Manage applications in S4 HANA disappear inte...
entry.content:
Hello @KevinV1 

This is usually not random authentication loss; it‚Äôs most often caused by Spaces/Pages, catalogue content, and the effects of personalisation or cache.

Quick checks

Is the app listed in App Finder?
If yes, it‚Äôs a page/personalisation issue. Reset user personalisation (User ‚Üí Settings ‚Üí Reset All Personalisation) or ask an admin to clear it for the user. SAP Support Portal/2661367 - Delete all user-created personalisation, such as groups (including My Home) - Fiori Launchpad      SAP Help Portal/Managing Your Settings

Use FLP Support / App Support tools to see exactly which catalogue or role provides the app and why it‚Äôs hidden. (Ctrl+Alt+Shift+P ‚Üí Launchpad/App Support). SAP Help Portal/Launchpad Support Tools

After upgrades, adopt catalogue changes in Maintain Business Roles (Manage Business Role Changes After Upgrade / Check for Changes). Missing adoptions can cause tiles to disappear until the role is updated. SAP Help Portal-Manage Business Role Changes After Upgrade, SAP Community-Review Business Role Changes before a Major Upgrade in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Browser/cache: test in Chrome Incognito to rule out local cache; empty spaces/pages can be auto hidden if they end up with no visible tiles. SAP Community-SAP Fiori launchpad: Hiding empty spaces and pages

If the app is not in App Finder, re-check the user‚Äôs business role,such as catalogue assignments, and adopt any pending changes, then test again.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Assistance Required for Invoking 'CreateFixedAsset' A...
entry.content:
Hi @alihassan_tahqeeq36 

Thank you for sharing the details of your scenario and the screenshots. I understand you are trying to invoke the CreateFixedAsset action from the Fixed Asset Master Data OData v4 API using SAP Cloud Integration but you are facing challenges since the action does not show up in the CPI adapter dropdown.

Here is how you can approach it step by step:

  1. Here is why the action does not appear in CPI

The CPI OData adapter is mainly designed for standard CRUD operations (GET, POST to entity sets, PUT, PATCH).
Bound actions like CreateFixedAsset are not exposed in the dropdown. Instead, they must be called directly via their dedicated endpoint URL.

  1. The Correct Endpoint

The action is invoked with a POST request to a URL like this:

<S4HC_URL>/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_fixedasset/srvd_a2x/sap/fixedasset/0001/FixedAssetSAP__self.CreateFixedAsset

  1. Below is how you can set this up in CPI
  1. In your iFlow, use an HTTP Receiver adapter instead of the OData adapter.
  2. Configure the adapter with:
    •  Method: POST
    • Address: the full action endpoint (see above)
    • Authentication: OAuth2 Client Credentials using the S/4HANA Cloud Communication Arrangement for scenario SAP_COM_0510 (Fixed Asset Integration).
    • Add the required HTTP headers such as Content-Type: application/json and Accept: application/json
  1. For the Payload, you will need to send the request body in JSON, matching the schema of the CreateFixedAsset action.
  2. About SAP__self, you noticed the SAP__self in the action definition, this simply means the action is bound to the entity itself. Technically, you just need to call the action URL directly as described above.
  3. I recommend testing the call first in Postman with the action endpoint, OAuth token, and payload. Once you confirm it works, replicate the same in your CPI iFlow.

I hope this gives you a clear path forward, Benjamin. Please let me know if you would like me to sketch a sample CPI iFlow design so you have a concrete template to start with.

I hope this provides the desired result. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: TRM payment date in Transaction Manager greyed out
entry.content:
Hello @slucic 

You are asking about the behaviour of the Payment Date field in financial transactions.

Here is why the Payment Date is Greyed Out in your scenario

  • In S/4HANA Public Cloud TRM, the Payment date is not a free-entry field.
  • It is system-derived from the due date and payment settings.
  • This is by design. The cash flow and posting logic always tie the payment date to the due date rules and the posting date.

Here is what you can configure

  1. Payment Terms or Flow Types
    • The shift between due date and actual payment execution date is controlled through flow types and payment terms configuration.
    • You can define that the execution date = due date plus X days.
  2. Adjust payment schedule
    • In Public Cloud, you cannot directly overwrite the Payment Date in the transaction.
    • Instead, you must configure payment offset rules in customizing (via SSCUIs in CBC) so that the system generates a payment date shifted by 5 days compared to the due date.
  3. Posting Date vs. Payment Date
    • The posting date always reflects the contractual due date as required.
    • The payment date then follows the offset rule.

There are limitations in Public Cloud which you should be aware of

  • Direct manual entry of Payment Date is not possible ‚Üí field is always greyed out in both Condition Details and Cash Flow.
  • Only configurable logic (via flow types and payment terms) can influence it.

See following references for more details:

  • Treasury and Risk Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • Scope Item 1G1 ‚Äì Treasury and Risk Management

I hope this provides the desired result. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Errors during ACT_TRANS in ECC EHP8 up-to-date installation
entry.content: The ACT_TRANS error is a symptom, not the root cause. It is highly probable that it is causing the RSDDCHECK inconsistencies Do not proceed with this installation. The system will be unstable

entry.title: Re: Build Process automation approval form request isn‚Äôt...
entry.content: Hi Cherry,

entry.title: Maintenance Order Cost Capitalize To Asset
entry.content:
Hi All,

Can we perform maintenance cost that leads to capitalization asset in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?

Thank you.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Asset Management

entry.title: Re: Build Process automation approval form request isn‚Äôt...
entry.content: I have check user emails there is no case distinction. User's are able to access the workzone but they are not receiving approval forms in the my inbox app of workzone.

entry.title: Re: Extra line items with zero value in settlement document
entry.content: Hi, YordanG has a point here. There is a mismatch between the split criteria for the settlement items and the accrual reversal items. If I have such an issue, then I use SE16N / SE16H to compare the settlement items. Especially considering the fields that are configured as split criteria.

entry.title: Re: An error occurs while deploying the Joule capability:...
entry.content: Did you manage to solve this? I am trying to deploy via the deploy button, but the same error of auth missing, which I do have

entry.title: Re: Maintenance Order Cost Capitalize To Asset
entry.content:
Yes as per these SAP documentations, it is possible that maintenance costs can be capitalized into assets in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Asset Management 

Asset Accounting

entry.title: Re: Errors during ACT_TRANS in ECC EHP8 up-to-date installation
entry.content: @mpavan_kumar I assumed as much so I've repeated the installation multiple times to try and address the errors before proceeding with this system. Despite implementing the recommended notes at the start of SUM I'm still getting the errors, so I cannot proceed. I don't know why I'm getting these errors on a fresh installation without any customizations. There were no errors during the SWPM part of the installation.

entry.title: Selection of optimal scenario for Selective Data Transition to SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
This article is part of a series exploring SAP's Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE). In a previous blog, we provided an overview and the main value drivers of the SDT transition approach. In this article, we will discuss the optimal selection of an SDT scenario. Upcoming instalments will delve into methodology, tools, and more to clarify SDTE and showcase its benefits.

 

Transformation requirements

Enterprises operating on SAP ERP and considering a transition to SAP S/4HANA may have varying starting points and needs. Some may see the transition as a move to the next generation of software with minimal changes in system functionality and data. Others may use the SAP S/4HANA transition to revamp their system's foundation to better support current and future business needs, eliminating obsolete data and developments while introducing new features and innovations. Transformation requirements often depend on:

  • How long ago and how optimally the SAP ERP systems were implemented, and how significantly business models, structures, and processes have changed since then.
  • How prepared the current systems are to support business strategy, growth, and innovations.
  • The roadmap chosen by the enterprise for transformation, including investments planned before, during, and after the transition to SAP S/4HANA.

Selective Data Transition provides the flexibility to incorporate desired changes within the scope of the SAP S/4HANA transition project, encompassing multiple transition scenarios rather than one. Different scenarios may be optimal for different enterprises based on transformation and data migration requirements.

In the following sections, we will explore these scenarios and discuss how to select the most suitable one for your specific requirements. We'll begin with an overview of options for creating the target system and then examine various data migration scenarios.

Target system creation

Every SDT project begins with the decision on how the target SAP S/4HANA system will be created. The target system, also known as the "golden shell" or "golden template," is a system created at the start of the SDT project. It serves as the foundation for all systems within the SAP S/4HANA project and maintenance landscapes, including the future productive system.

Option 1. Shell conversion

The first option, "shell conversion," is suitable if most of your current SAP ERP assets (configured solutions, developments, data) need to be preserved and transitioned to SAP S/4HANA.

  1. Using a client copy or specific tools, create an empty copy of SAP ECC with all customizing and repository (code) but without any application data. This system is called the "SAP ECC shell."
  2. Perform required housekeeping activities in the empty SAP ECC shell system, such as removing unnecessary company codes. Unicode conversion or upgrades may be completed to meet system conversion prerequisites if required.
  3. Execute all activities necessary to prepare this system for conversion to SAP S/4HANA (data preparation is not required since there is no data in the system).
  4. Convert the prepared SAP ECC shell to SAP S/4HANA using a standard conversion toolset and complete SPAU, SPDD and post-conversion activities. This system becomes the "golden shell" of SAP S/4HANA‚Äîa template for all future SAP S/4HANA systems, created as copies of the golden shell.
  5. Implement custom code adjustments and customizing changes required for simplification items or additional business requirements in the development system (a copy of the golden shell).
  6. Necessary data can be migrated to the copy of the configured system. More details on data migration scenarios described below.

Option 2. Mix and Match

The second option is suitable when most processes require modifications, and it becomes necessary to substantially reimplement the system. This approach supports these changes while retaining certain investments, such as configured solutions, developments, and data, for the transition to SAP S/4HANA.

In this scenario, a new SAP S/4HANA system is deployed, with standard content activated as necessary. Unlike a greenfield implementation, the target system will be enhanced by transferring selected elements from SAP ECC or an intermediate ECC system. This enhancement is supported by specialized tools.

The most common scenarios are illustrated in the image above.

Option 3. Special case ‚Äì Systems Consolidation

When it is necessary to consolidate multiple SAP ECC systems into a single instance of SAP S/4HANA, and there are significant similarities among the ECC systems, variations of options 1 and 2 can be utilized to create the target system, depending on specific requirements. A typical scenario is as follows:

  1. Select one of the consolidated systems as the main target.
  2. Create an SAP ECC shell from this system.
  3. Compare customization and repository of this SAP ECC shell with all the SAP ECC systems that will be consolidated manually or using specific tools, highlighting any identified differences.
  4. Analyze the differences and document how to resolve conflicts, collecting mappings between settings in the source and target systems to be used in the later data migration.
  5. Consolidate customizing and repositories in the SAP ECC shell system manually or using special tools based on documented decisions.
  6. Prepare the consolidated SAP ECC shell for conversion to SAP S/4HANA and convert it into the golden shell of SAP S/4HANA.

Once the target system is ready, an SAP S/4HANA development system is usually created as a copy to perform necessary application-specific customizing and custom-code adjustments. Completion of these prepares the system for data migration and testing.

SDT Scenarios Overview

SDT scenarios described below represent best practices commonly used in SDTE community projects. Even if the terms or names may slightly vary among different partners, the meaning and practices remain consistent within the community. After creating the target SAP S/4HANA system, finding an optimal path for data migration addressing specific requirements is essential.

Scenario 1. Regular SDT ‚Äì table-based data migration and transformation

In this scenario, selected SAP ERP system data is migrated to SAP S/4HANA at the database table level using specialized tools. Specific considerations include:

  • Target system creation is preferably achieved via the shell conversion.
  • Table-based migration enables fast data transfer, resulting in short downtime since migration occurs at the database level. Unlike posting based technology (e.g. Migration Cockpit) no application-level logic is executed for the data migration, thus careful data validation and process testing is crucial post-migration.
  • Required transformation routines are executed in the SAP S/4HANA target system post or during migration to transform the data into the SAP S/4HANA data model.
  • Historical transactional data can be migrated using this approach, with filters applicable based on organizational units (e.g., data for selected company codes) or time slices (e.g., the last three years of data), or individual filters for data migration objects. Data cleansing and preparation of the migrated data in source systems may be needed (for example consistency of finance historical data).
  • Go-live can be scheduled at any time during the fiscal year, as all necessary data for finance reporting is usually migrated, avoiding data slicing between systems.
  • Downtime for source and target systems is usually required during the table-based migration.
  • Transformations can be applied to migrated data based on mappings, renaming, or renumbering logic. Some S/4HANA transformation pre-projects (e.g., Business Partners creation) may be embedded in the SDT migration process. However, limitations may exist on integrating many "on-the-fly" transformations simultaneously on the same data set at the same time.

Scenario 2. Lean SDT ‚Äì table-based data migration without transformation requirements

Lean Selective Data Transition is the standard solution provided by SAP for identifying and transferring relevant data during migration from SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA using the SAP Business Transformation Center. Technically, Lean SDT resembles Option 1: shell creation is necessary, and all data migrates at the table level with organizational unit or time slice filters. However, Lean SDT offers no data transformations and no systems consolidation, whereas regular SDT provides more flexibility and broader transformation possibilities.

Scenario 3. Hybrid SDT ‚Äì combination of table-based data migration & postings

In this scenario, selected SAP ERP data for specific areas (e.g., master data, logistics, plant maintenance) migrated to SAP S/4HANA at the database table level using special tools, while postings (using tools like SAP Migration Cockpit or specific consulting tools) are used for other data objects (e.g., finance open items, balances, and inventory stocks). Specific considerations include:

  • Postings trigger application-level validations of migrated data, increasing confidence in data quality within the target system. However, postings may take longer than table-based migration and require higher data cleansing standards.
  • Historical transactional data cannot be migrated using standard posting methodologies. Only current open orders, open items, balances, and stocks can be transferred to the target instance.
  • Go-live is advisable at the beginning of the fiscal year, as data needed for finance reporting may be sliced between systems otherwise, impacting migration scope and efforts (P&L, assets).
  • Postings occur through data re-creation using API (BAPI) in the target system considering local system settings. Therefore, postings provide a simplified option to redesign functional and structural changes, at the expense of loss of historical data.

SDT Scenario Selection

Selecting an optimal SDT scenario is primarily driven by transformation and data migration requirements and includes decisions on the target system creation option and data migration approach.

Decision on a target system creation option depends on the changes needed in the system functionality and structures. This influences the scope of the transformation. The shell creation approach predominantly reuses current SAP ERP system customizing and repository, indicating that migrated data mostly fits the new system as it is in the source. The Mix and Match approach suggests that primarily spot solutions will remain unchanged in the future SAP S/4HANA compared to the current SAP ERP, starting from a new fresh system reducing the data migration scope/volume and increasing complexity of transformation.

To select an optimal data migration strategy, it is essential to identify, at least at a high level, the mandatory and desired functional and structural changes (transformations) that will occur in the new SAP S/4HANA system compared to the existing SAP ERP. This question is closely related to data migration scope. Migrating historical transactional data means all required transformations must occur within this data, which can be complex and challenging for certain transformations and data objects.

Project risks, efforts, and duration can be managed with a balanced approach between functional transformations and data migration scope. If functional transformations are driven by changes in business models and processes, they cannot usually be sacrificed and must be executed during the SAP S/4HANA transition. In such cases, data migration scope can be limited to postings of master data and open items to new structures in heavily transformed areas.

Other factors influencing scenario selection include planned go-live date (beginning of fiscal year or not), systems consolidation needs, data volumes, downtime requirements, and potential for transformational pre- or post-projects.

To summarize, selecting the optimal SDT scenario requires knowledge of:

  • Mandatory and desired functional and structural changes (transformations) in the new SAP S/4HANA system compared to the existing SAP ERP.
  • Required data migration scope in different areas (Finance, Logistics/Operation, HR).
  • Downtime, go-live date, system consolidation, and other special requirements.

These topics must be discussed all together since they influence each other. A balanced approach might be required to select the most optimal SDT scenario that will provide the safest, easiest, and fastest pathway to SAP S/4HANA target architecture.

Success Stories

German manufacturer in the food sector: Selective Data Transition of the last 2 years

The customer moved document date from the last two years from his old ECC into S/4HANA environment.

SDTE Properties in Action:

  • Shell creation: Technical preparation of the future S/4HANA target system
  • Filtered selection: Time slice level to just bring the necessary organizational structures with current and last two fiscal year into the new environment
  • SDT transformation approach: CO area restructuring (mainly merging, but also some splits), chart of accounts harmonization, introduction of New GL and New Asset Accounting, introduction of group currency

Energy Industry (Germany): Selective Data Transition with filtered migration

The customer moved from his 20-year-old SAP ECC into a new SAP S/4HANA environment including a separation of energy industry specific data (SAP IS-U) from core ERP logistic and finance data.

SDTE Properties in Action:

  • Shell creation: Technical preparation of the future S/4HANA target system
  • Filtered selection: Filter on organizational and time slice level to just bring the necessary organizational structures with current and last fiscal year into the new environment
  • SDT transformation approach: Regular SDT including transformations like a controlling area split and bringing the data into the S/4HANA data model

Call to Action

You‚Äôve seen that selecting an optimal SDT scenario is primarily driven by transformation and data migration scope requirements and includes decisions on the target system creation option and data migration approach.

In the next episode, we will discuss the advantages of systems consolidation and SDT usage for that purpose.

In the meantime:

  1. Explore Webinars & Resources
    Discover more about SDTE via official SAP Support Portal webinars or community sessions that dive deeper into the specifics.
  2. Contact the SDTE Community
    Reach out to the expert group of SAP and its partners for an assessment of your current landscape. They can help identify how selective data transition can best fit your needs.
  3. Start Your Transformation
    Don‚Äôt wait until maintenance windows close or all experts are not available anymore. A well-planned selective data migration can future-proof your IT environment and jump-start your intelligent enterprise journey.

Take the next step by visiting
SDTE Engagement Overview
to connect with the SDTE community and chart out your custom path to SAP S/4HANA success.

entry.title: VDA Automotive Flat File Processing with B2B Integration Factory
entry.content:
Introduction

Hello dear B2B Integration Community,

In many automotive supply chain scenarios, the ability to process VDA flat files, as specified by the German Automotive Industry Association, remains a critical requirement for seamless EDI communication.

While support for these specific formats is still pending in the standard SAP Integration Suite product roadmap and foreseen to be delivered by Q2/2026:

the B2B Integration Factory has already stepped in to fill this gap.

Thanks to its flexible and agile development approach, the B2B Integration Factory currently supports the processing of VDA automotive flat files, enabling customers in the automotive sector to proceed with their B2B integration projects without waiting for the standard product release.
Although the OFTP adapter is not currently available, the associated integration content can still be migrated and validated, allowing customers to prepare and move forward with their B2B integration projects.

 

What needs to be configured - General

1. Integration Content Deployment

Update and deploy the latest changes of the B2B Integration Factory packages, particularly:

  • B2B Integration Factory - Cloud Integration - Trading Partner Management v1.8.0
  • B2B Integration Factory - Extended Interchange Processing Flows v1.3.0
  • B2B Integration Factory - Interchange Extraction Flows v1.4.0
2. Create a Message Implementation Guideline (MIG)

Upload the VDA .xsd as a Custom Message into the Integration Advisor and create the VDA MIG:

3. Trading Partner setup

Leverage an available message type as a placeholder in the type system, in the Trading Partner Profile and then in the Trading Partner Agreement, even if it's not originally intended for this purpose, such as VDA EDIFACT for instance:

Converting XML to VDA Flat File

As already known from the IDocXML to IDocFlat Blog we will maintain the exact same two activity parameter keys in the TPA:
SAP_EDI_REC_Payload_Format = VDA-Automotive
SAP_B2B_Syntax_Conversion_ProcessFlowAddress = /tpm/syntax-conversion/VDA-Automotive

This conversion approach is independent of the specific message type and can be applied universally across different VDA formats

Additionally, I recommend to maintain two additional parameters:
SAP_REC_Assembly_Process_Flow_Indicator = false
SAP_EDI_REC_Document_Standard = VDA AUTOMOTIVE

The first one tells that an assembly procedure is not needed and the second is to populate the correct Receiver Document Standard in the B2B Monitoring. The TPA looks like this:

And in B2B Monitoring:

Here we can see a successful tranformation from an DESADV IDoc to a VDA 4913 Flat file.
Additionaly, you can set the parameter SAP_VDA_Automotive_To_Flat_Apply_Max_Length. It is per default set to true. If you do not want to apply the max length as defined in the .xsd then simply set the parameter in the TPA to false.

Converting VDA Flat File to XML

For this case, only one activity parameter is required to set the right Sender Document Standard. There are two optional parameters which follow the same naming convention as in my previous blog where I talk about migration PI/PO content to Cloud Integration TPM. If you want to keep the content from your legacy PI/PO then the Namespace as well as the Namespace Prefix matters for the PI/PO message mapping. These can be maintained in the relevant BTA. Parameter Private values are SAP_B2B_MM_Namespace and SAP_B2B_MM_Namespace_Prefix. Here is an example BTA:

In this case, I am converting a VDA 4905 Flat file to its corresponding VDA 4905 XML as the target. At the receiver interchange level I am again misusing the type system IDoc wheras I am using VDA AUTOMOTIVE.

This conversion approach is also independent of the specific message type and can be applied universally across different VDA formats.

Result in B2B Monitoring:

 

Outlook

The ability to process VDA automotive flat files using the B2B Integration Factory‚Äîeven ahead of standard product support‚Äîdemonstrates SAP‚Äôs commitment to agility, extensibility, and customer-centric innovation in the B2B integration space.

As the automotive industry continues to rely on flat file formats like VDA for critical EDI processes, this early enablement empowers customers to move forward with migration and modernization efforts without delay.

Organizations that adopt this approach today will be well-positioned to seamlessly transition to future product enhancements, with minimal rework and full alignment to SAP‚Äôs integration roadmap.

entry.title: Re: S4HANA Public Cloud - CBO Upsert Error 'Expected type...
entry.content:
Hello @RWeidner 

Your call is failing because the CBO sap_upsert must be invoked with POST and a JSON body, not by passing parameters in the URL. When you include parameters in the query string, the gateway treats them as strings, leading to the error Expected type is Edm.Boolean.

What to do (works reliably in Public Cloud):

Call the function import with POST + JSON

POST /sap/opu/odata/sap/YY1_API_TEST_CDS/YY1_API_TESTSap_upsert

Content-Type: application/json

Accept: application/json

{

  "NumericID": "0000000001",

  "CheckBox": true,

  "Amount": 1.00

}

  • CheckBox must be a JSON boolean: true or false (no quotes).
  • Decimals can be sent as numbers in JSON; the service will type them as Edm. Decimal from metadata. SAP Help Portal

If you only want to quick-test via URL (GET)

  • Use OData V2 literal rules:
    • Boolean: CheckBox=true (lowercase, no quotes)
    • Decimal: add the M suffix, e.g. Amount=1.00M
      Example:

.../YY1_API_TEST_CDS/YY1_API_TESTSap_upsert?

  NumericID='0000000001'&CheckBox=true&Amount=1.00M

  • (But the supported pattern for sap_upsert is POST with a body.) odata.org-URI Conventions (OData Version 2.0)

Double-check names and types in $metadata
Open the service $metadata and verify the FunctionImport parameter names and EDM types match what you send. If the parameter name differs from the entity field name, you must use the function import‚Äôs parameter name. odata.org-Operations (OData Version 2.0)

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: BAPI EXTENSION for VBKD
entry.content:
It works.  Do a enhancement within FORM USEREXIT_MOVE_FIELD_TO_VBKD, then import zfield  from memeory.

 

  DATA:
        lt_zsd_so_vbkd_zfield TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF zsd_so_vbkd_zfield.
  IMPORT lt_zsd_so_vbkd_zfield FROM MEMORY ID 'ZSD_SO_VBKD_ZFIELD'.
  read table lt_zsd_so_vbkd_zfield with key posnr = vbkd-posnr into data(ls_zfield).
  if sy-subrc = 0.
    vbkd-ZZSDABW = ls_zfield-zzsdabw.
    vbkd-ZZTDDAT = ls_zfield-ZZTDDAT.
    vbkd-ZZGRKOR = ls_zfield-ZZGRKOR.
    vbkd-ZZKZTLF = ls_zfield-ZZKZTLF.
  endif.

entry.title: SAP CodeJam Roadshow LATAM 2025 - recap
entry.content:
And that's a wrap..... Together with @josh_bentley, @RichHeilman, @thomas_jung, @SavioMarques, @jessicademarchi and @caiograbalos, we did a few SAP CodeJams in Latin America - four different cities (S√£o Paulo üáßüá∑, Lima üáµüá™, Mexico City üá≤üáΩ and Bogota üá®üá¥), various meetups and even joined the SAP Inside Track in S√£o Paulo. As part of the roadshow, we run the Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core and ABAP Cloud & ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model CodeJams. It is always great to meet community members where they are and learn about the challenges they face in the different project and how SAP products enable them to tackle these.

 

This is the 2nd roadshow we've done in the region, and what a great experience it was. It was great to meet in person many SAP community members that I've interacted with online in the past. As well as seeing some familiar faces in the locations that we visited in the 1st LATAM roadshow.

S√£o Paulo üáßüá∑

@josh_bentley already share a recap of the events in Brazil and the first event in Peru.... so go ahead and check out all the photos he is sharing in the blog post - https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-codejam-discussions/sap-codejam-roadshow-latam-2025-the-first-half-recap-being-present-is-about/td-p/14173987 

Lima üáµüá™

This is the first time we've done CodeJams in Lima, hosted at the SAP office. It was great to meet the local community and lovely to enjoy some of the local cuisine and coffee :-). Thanks to everyone who joined, even though there was a holiday right in the middle of the week #PeruEsClave.

 

 

 

 

 

Mexico City üá≤üáΩ

Two amazing events hosted at the IBM offices in Mexico City. I got the opportunity to meet SAP Champions - @Sandra_Solis and @MariettaLopez, whom I've interacted with in the past but never before met in person. Also, Devtoberfest winners - @Sandra_Solis and @eamarce23. Thanks to IBM for hosting, looking forward to more events in Mexico :-). The day after the CodeJams we also had the opportunity to visit the Museo Nacional de Antropologia time and get some time to learn about the different Mexican indigenous cultures.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


 

 

 

 

 

Bogota üá®üá¥

Last city part of the 2nd LATAM CodeJam roadshow. The day before the events, there was some time to explore the city a bit and visit the Museo Botero, as well as the Casa de Moneda. The events took place @ the SAP office in Bogota. It was great to catch up with various previous CodeJam attendees, as well as meet some more community members. Special mention to the large crew who joined the CodeJams from Globant (Bogota and Cali).... next time we will organise the event at the Globant office haha

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


 


 

Personally, I always feel energised after connecting with the large Latin American SAP community and I know that it is also a great experience for the other advocates that have joined the roadshows. I'm already looking forward to next year and doing more CodeJams in the region.

entry.title: Re: calculating depreciatio in SAP SAC Advance formula
entry.content:
// Assumptions:
// - [d/Measures].[AssetCost] = cost of asset
// - [d/Measures].[Depreciation] = target measure
// - [d/Asset].[UsefulLife] = property (in years)
// - [d/Asset].[EndDate] = property in YYYYMM format (e.g. 202603)
// - [d/Version].[StartPeriod], [d/Version].[EndPeriod] = properties in YYYYMM

FOREACH [d/Asset]

DATA(assetCost) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures].[AssetCost]);
DATA(usefulLife) = NUMBER(PROPERTY([d/Asset].[d/Asset].[#],"UsefulLife"));
DATA(endDate) = NUMBER(PROPERTY([d/Asset].[d/Asset].[#],"EndDate"));

DATA(budgetStart)= NUMBER(PROPERTY([d/Version].[d/Version].[#],"StartPeriod"));
DATA(budgetEnd) = NUMBER(PROPERTY([d/Version].[d/Version].[#],"EndPeriod"));

// Only if asset cost > 0
IF(assetCost <> 0)

// Monthly depreciation
DATA(monthDep) = assetCost / (usefulLife * 12);

// Depreciation start = EndDate + 1 month
DATA(depStart) = ADDMONTHS(endDate,1);

// Depreciation end = MIN(depStart + life*12 -1 , budgetEnd)
DATA(depEnd) = MIN( ADDMONTHS(depStart, usefulLife*12 - 1), budgetEnd );

// Loop through time periods
FOR(cur = depStart; cur <= depEnd; cur = ADDMONTHS(cur,1))
RESULT([d/Measures].[Depreciation],[d/Time].[cur]) = monthDep;
ENDFOR;

ENDIF;

ENDFOR;

entry.title: Re: Selective data migration approach
entry.content:
Hi Venkat

Great discussion on the selective data transition approach! For organizations looking to streamline S/4HANA migration, using specialized data migration tools can make a huge difference‚Äîespecially for Finance, Asset Management, and P2P modules. PiLog offers a comprehensive suite of Data Migration solutions that support end-to-end ETL processes, ensuring data accuracy, consistency, and compliance during the migration.

entry.title: The limited no of documents in the Trial version of SAP Document AI must increase to make sense
entry.content:
Hi 

Depending on where you read documentation, the limited no of document that can be loaded in a Trial DOX is either 30 or 50 documents per month - with the addition that it counts one document per every 3 pages in a file.

This very little - almost useless. On top of this the usage statistics in BTP are unreliable, so the counted usage is higher than reality.

I have a BTP trial account with a trial DOX where I have loaded 17 document. 7 in August and 10 in September, but the usage statistics says I have loaded 40 documents in September and now my quota is used. I know 100% sure I loaded the same document 10 times in september and the document was only 2 pages, so it should count 10 documents instead of 40.

Also it is frustrating that the usage statistics says I loaded 47 documents, but even if that was correct (it isn't), the documentation says that the quota is 50 documents per 30 days (rolling period), so according to documentation my quota is not used in any way.

 


If SAP wants to sell SAP Document AI, they should increase the quota. If we can't really test it, why should we buy it?

Also I find it disturbing that the usage statistics count usage that does not exist. I have seen this problem not only in trail versions, but also in Pay-As-You-Go.

Just my 2 cents.

Thomas Madsen Nielsen

entry.title: Re: Material Master Data Mass Maintenance - Delete value...
entry.content:
Hello @Emi1 

Thank you for sharing the details and screenshots regarding your attempt to mass delete EAN/UPC and EAN Category values from the product master in S/4HANA Public Cloud. Apologies for the very late response. Hope these details will still provide some good insights.

After reviewing the scenario, here is the clarification and recommended approach:

Here is why the Error in your scenario occurs

  • The EAN/UPC information is stored in table MEAN as a child entity of the product master.
  • The Mass Maintenance Products app does not support the deletion of GTIN records.
  • As a result, simply clearing the field values during mass maintenance has no effect because the system ignores blank overwrites for these dependent entities. Using an action code D results in the error: Deletion not allowed for GTIN (MEAN) or one of its children.
  • This is standard system behaviour in the Public Cloud environment to protect data integrity.

Supported Options in Public Cloud

  1. Individual Deletion via Product Master Apps
    • It is possible to manually delete EANs in the Change Product Master Data app under Basic Data.
    • However, this is not practical for your volume
  2. Data Migration Cockpit
    • Use the Migration Object: Product to reload products with blank GTIN data.
    • When executed in update/overwrite mode, this can clear existing EAN values.
    • This is suitable if you prefer a migration-style one-time cleanup.
  3. Product Master OData API
    • The API allows direct DELETE calls on the GTIN entity for a given product and unit of measure.
    • This is SAP‚Äôs recommended method for handling bulk deletions programmatically in Public Cloud.
    • You could script the calls or use CPI/iFlow to automate deletion for all 10k records.

However, these are not possible

  • Mass Maintenance Products cannot be used for GTIN deletions rather only for updates.
  • Direct table deletes are not permitted in Public Cloud due to clean-core restrictions.

The following are the recommended steps

Given the number of records (10k), the most efficient approaches would be either:

  • Use Data Migration Cockpit in overwrite mode, or
  • Leverage the Product Master API to programmatically delete GTINs.

See the references below for further details

Product Master API (A2X)

Mass Changes Products App Documentation

I hope this provides the desired result. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: E2E process ‚ÄúAcquire to Decommission‚Äù and Enterprise Asset Management solution portfolio overvie
entry.content:
This is a really insightful overview of SAP‚Äôs Enterprise Asset Management capabilities. At PiLog, we approach EAM by looking at the full lifecycle of an asset, from acquisition all the way through to decommissioning. Managing the entire lifecycle helps organizations keep maintenance organized, improve asset performance, and make sure the data stays accurate at every step.

Some key aspects of a holistic EAM approach include:

  • Integrating data across systems so asset information is consistent and reliable.

  • Using AI and IoT sensor data to anticipate maintenance needs before issues arise.

  • Coordinating maintenance and resources efficiently, especially in asset-heavy industries.

  • Encouraging collaboration across teams and external partners through shared asset information.

Looking at assets this way helps organizations operate more smoothly, reduce unexpected downtime, and make more informed decisions about asset usage and maintenance.

You can explore more about managing assets throughout their lifecycle here: Enduring Asset Lifecycle Management
